column1: A further complication is the necessity of establishing authentic “Indianness”, both in the eyes of fellow indigenous peoples and the outside Spanish culture. [SEP] The ONIC of Colombia lacks legitimacy precisely because it is perceived as not “Indian enough”; it embraces the use of Spanish and Western discourse, leading to distrust among indigenous peoples (Jackson 2002: 85). [SEP] Politicians make a point of appearing in their native dress and speaking in their native language in assembly, even if they are more at home in a business suit and speaking Spanish; indigenous identity has be
column3: a calling card to the extent that at times it appears to be a caricature of itself. [SEP] The Colombian constitution is problematic in that it provides little guide as to what exactly forms an indigenous group; the concept of culture is so complex and divergent that establishing self-determination in the eyes of the Colombian government requires emphasizing differences. [SEP] Efforts towards development, then, cannot endanger traditional culture and values, for fear of losing cultural legitimacy (Jackson 1995: 5). [SEP] There develops a duality in native culture; for example, many Nasa children receive instruction in Nasa Yuwe yet converse in Spanish outside the classroom. [SEP] An emphasis on preserving, rather than practicing, native culture arises: indigenous authenticity is maintained b

column1: tók is one of the many early-twentieth century composers whose music fits entirely in the gray area between tonality and atonality. [SEP] While we know from his writings that he often composed with a tonal centers and relationships in mind, and that he regularly applied tonal structures and forms to his compositions, by merely glancing at any one of his pieces we can see that tonality as it is understood in the common practice period is not at work. [SEP] Thanks largely to the work of tonal theorists such as Heinrich Schenker and others, we have a detailed system for analyzing tonal music—their system, however, is virtually useless in analyzing music that falls entirely on the atonal side of the spectrum. [SEP] But if we apply it to music such as Bartók’s that is in the middle area, we can
column3: up with some enlightening and perhaps unexpected results. [SEP] To do so was the goal of this analysis of the first movement of the Concerto for Orchestra. [SEP] By applying our tonal system to music that slips outside of the tonal realm, we not only find the elements of tonality that do remain, but we also pinpoint exactly when and how this music breaks from previous conventions. [SEP] It is not disputed that Bartók’s music has great expressive power—perhaps now we can understand why. [SEP] References

column1: Sequels: 45762 As soon as Psyche had repeated the dreary process and stepped out of the Underworld, she breathed in the clean air. [SEP] A musty smell clung to her lungs. [SEP] She began to walk, slowly, back to Aphrodite’s “house,” when arrogance started to take over her. [SEP] Very few living people had
column3: out of the Underworld. [SEP] Surely Aphrodite would let her see her husband again, and when that happened, she had to be presentable. [SEP] She was sure her hair and face were a mess. [SEP] Psyche’s eyes fell on the box of cosmetics. [SEP] A little touch here and there couldn’t hurt. [SEP] She carefully cracked the box open – and collapsed. [SEP] Eros’s voice was getting hoarse when he saw her lying on the ground, her form crumpled. [SEP] He swept over to her body and picked her up in his arms. [SEP] “Foolish little Psyche,” he murmured as he wiped the drug off her eyelids. [SEP] Admiring her face once more, Eros opened his wingspan and flew off to Zeus’s palace. column1: Sequels: 45853 It was as bleak as a day could get, the day the angel fell from the heavens. [SEP] It was a cold day in November, and the only sign of life was the wind, hissing between the brown grasses and the lifeless tree branches. [SEP] The ground was littered with shriveled leaves that occasionally were lifted by the wind to travel several feet before dropping back to the dull grass. [SEP] At first I thought that the winged shape in the sky was a sparrow, and I was glad that a bird had
column3: out, for it was lonely with just the hissing wind for company. [SEP] But as it descended, it grew larger. [SEP] It was a goose. [SEP] No, all the geese had left for the winter, and it was too large now. [SEP] What was it? [SEP] An eagle? [SEP] Could it be? [SEP] No, it was too large, and it’s wings weren’t open. [SEP] It wasn’t descending with control, but falling. [SEP] The creature was the flapping wildly, trying to regain flight, but it still fell, falling, falling, down to earth. [SEP] Eagle's Beak

column1: I danced with Rachel for a while, but then something by the bar seemed to be pulling her eyes. [SEP] She told me that she was heading for a drink and slipped out of the crowd. [SEP] When she hadn’t
column3: back halfway through the next song, I glanced over at the bar. [SEP] It was just a little set-up where someone had stacked a few crates and brought something alcoholic to share, mostly beer. [SEP] Rachel was standing with a plastic cup, looking like she was having a conversation, but I couldn’t see anyone else there. [SEP] The next time the crowd split, I saw him. [SEP] He stood in front of a blue light, so I couldn’t see him clearly, but what I saw was memorable. [SEP] He wore a jacket of what might have been blue velvet, and his hair gleamed black against his white skin. [SEP] The blue haze seemed to stop just shy of his pallor, setting off his striking face without illuminating its details, and his wrists flashed white in the darkness. [SEP] He didn’t move, just stared and held his drink

column1: The next time I saw them, his mouth was moving. [SEP] She nodded and he took her arm. [SEP] I watched them through the crush of dancers as they squeezed along the wall, and the feeling came to me that something was very wrong. [SEP] Saturday morning, I woke up and saw that she still hadn’t
column3: home. [SEP] I called Mitch and our other friends, hoping that she’d crashed at one of their houses, but I had no luck. [SEP] A couple of them remembered seeing her leave, but none of them had seen the thin man with her. [SEP] I didn’t know how they could miss such exotic features, even in that distorting light. [SEP] I caught a taxi back to the church. [SEP] It was still a mess, but everything bigger than a soda can had disappeared. [SEP] I walked across what had been the dance floor. [SEP] The church was completely different now: sunlight fell through the stained glass, catching dust that still hung in the air and sending a dry, healthy warmth into the edges of the room, through the stone and the powdery concrete that had been covered last night by flesh and flashing lights. [SEP] I realiz

column1: ch was completely different now: sunlight fell through the stained glass, catching dust that still hung in the air and sending a dry, healthy warmth into the edges of the room, through the stone and the powdery concrete that had been covered last night by flesh and flashing lights. [SEP] I realized that Rachel had disappeared without leaving a clue and I had no way to do anything but wait for her to show up – which, if she were in a situation where I should be doing something, would probably be never. [SEP] Standing in the center of the church, I took out my cell phone and called the police. [SEP] “I need to file a missing persons report. …Rachel Frieze. Last night, walking on West 2nd street around – maybe eleven or twelve o’clock. What? …But, sir, this is an unusual situation. She didn’t
column3: home last night, none of her friends have seen her. …Sir, if she’s in any danger, it will probably be too late to help her by that time. My girlfriend has disappeared, I don’t even know where to start looking, and I need help! …Yes, sir. I understand.” [SEP] The police wouldn’t file a report for someone who’d been missing overnight. [SEP] I closed the phone. [SEP] Walking out of the church, a little gust of cold air caught me by surprise. [SEP] A cold front must have hit while I was inside. [SEP] Glancing down the street, I realized that I didn’t have a friend to drive me home this time, and it was a long walk back to the streets where taxis ran. [SEP] I pulled my T-shirt’s sleeves down my arms as far as they’d go, but I wasn’t ready for cold.

column1: Then there was a door, which opened as we approached. [SEP] Inside, the space opened into a wide, square chamber mirrored and so dark that it could have been any size. [SEP] In the center was a dais covered with white furs and a young woman, surrounded by more pale men. [SEP] These were incontestably male. [SEP] “Nepthys!” said the woman, slithering up across the furs to sit up. [SEP] As she rose, her robes fell open and I realized that, except for what looked like a red silk kimono, she was naked – naked and stunning. [SEP] I had an urge to cover Amy’s eyes. [SEP] “It’s been years since I’ve seen you. Please,
column3: and sit beside me, and introduce your friends.” “This man is here in search of his lover, who was stolen from him in the human world,” said Nepthys, ushering us toward the woman in silk. [SEP] “The girl is …surprising,” he concluded.

column1: His face soft as if caught between a smile and tears, he draped his loose cape over her shoulders. [SEP] "Come, darling," he whispered. [SEP] "Where I am to take you, one need never think of those left behind." [SEP] They took their seats within the car and his driver set the horses trotting. [SEP] For a few yards, they kicked up dust along the roadway; then they raised their hooves and took to the air. column3: to her by his hand. [SEP] The New England woods disappeared, even the greatest pines shrinking to insignificance as they mounted the sky. column1: y his house and began frantically throwing handfuls of water onto the pyre. [SEP] His thoughts were not of the act's futility, nor even of the nights spent tormented by the twisted thing; instead, all that filled his mind was the tree's constant presence in his life, growing with him and beside him, its persistent reminders that he had higher, truer things to write, the simple beauty of the great black tree for its own sake. [SEP] His handfuls could do nothing to quench the hewn, burning logs, but when the night sky grew dark above him and the fire dwindled to black ashes, tears threatened to spill forth and extinguish the final embers. [SEP] But he did not weep. [SEP] Instead, he bethought himself of the loss of the tree; considered also Arthur's motivation and whether some good might not
column3: of this, after all. [SEP] Leaving the circle of ashes, he stood and turned towards the woods, in which it was his habit to walk when in a pensive mood. [SEP] He stepped slowly beneath the branches, a gust of wind stirring up the ashes behind him in a great, swirling eddy, a burning brand that rose up and dispersed on the winds as though it were the willow's last breath. [SEP] Allan wandered beneath the trees for a time, thoughts drifting through his mind like great banks of fog, strangely beautiful but impossible to penetrate. [SEP] He considered Arthur's intervention; considered that it might be better to accept the fog and continue as his lifelong friend had suggested, to write stories that others would read; for after all, what purpose writing if not to be read? column1: USSRSOS Some new information has
column3: to light over the Kursk disaster. [SEP] (For those with short attention spans, the Kursk was the submarine that blew up and sank in the Arctic Ocean killing all 118 on board.) [SEP] The Russians tried to blame the incident on a collision with an unidentified object. [SEP] However, sonar tapes which recorded the blasts (a small one at first, then a much larger one, two minutes later), cast doubt on these claims. [SEP] A whistle-blower within the Russian military has leaked that the crew of the Kursk was testing a new type of torpedo when the accident occurred. [SEP] It seemed very likely that the test didn't go quite as planned. column1: Price records are being set at auctions this week. [SEP] At Christie's, a folio of 21 prints from Alfred Stieglitz's "Equivalents" series sold for $396,000, a single-lot record. [SEP] Other works also have been exceeding price estimates. [SEP] In part, prices reflect development of a market structure based on such variables as the number of prints. [SEP] This information used to be poorly documented and largely anecdotal, says Beth Gates-Warren of Sotheby's. [SEP] "There is finally some sort of sense in the market," she says. [SEP] Corporations and museums are among the serious buyers, giving greater market stability, says Robert Persky of the Photograph Collector. [SEP] "When I see prints going into the hands of institutions, I know they aren't going to
column3: back on the market." [SEP] Most in demand: classic photographs by masters such as Stieglitz and Man Ray. [SEP] But much contemporary work is also fetching "a great deal of money," says Miles Barth of the International Center of Photography. [SEP] DIALING 900 brings callers a growing number of services.

column1: Zozobra A giant, forty-foot effigy in the form of a puppet, which is burned during the annual Santa Fe Fiesta held in Santa Fe, New Mexico. [SEP] The word Zozobra translates to “gloom” or “worry” or “anguished.” [SEP] The Zozobra is ritualistically burned at the beginning of the fiesta, which symbolizes the end of destructiveness, gloom, and worry, setting the tone for a successful fiesta. [SEP] The creation of Zozobra was introduced into the fiesta in 1926 by Will Shuster, who felt that the fiesta had be
column3: “dull and commercialized.” [SEP] Throughout the years the image of Zozobra changed from a simple twenty-foot puppet to the elaborate forty-foot figure with animated eyes, arms, and mouth that he is today. [SEP] In 1969 Shuster turned over the responsibility and copyright of Zozobra to the Kiwanis Club of Santa Fe. [SEP] He is hung on a tall pole on a hill, outside the city, where the burning can be seen by the thousands of people who

[SEP] We reinterpret the contributions of these authors by explicitly re-framing them within Weick’s framework (and we emphasise it is these three authors, and their original descriptions and ideas, that deserve the major part of the credit for this chapter). [SEP] To show how enactment and associated principles of self-organising and learning
column3: to life, we will trace the process of enactment in each setting. [SEP] First, we will describe the factors that have contributed to boundaryless career forms in each example. [SEP] Next, we will cite some of the characteristics that make the resulting circumstances ‘weak’. [SEP] After that we will discuss the social behaviour and collective actions that fill the resulting void in the environment. [SEP] Finally, we will point out the patterns, order, and shape we see enactment bringing to each of these respective settings. [SEP] By doing so we hope to convey the pervasive qualities of both the process of enactment and the vehicle through which it operates – the boundaryless career. [SEP] The Silicon Valley

column1: The Silicon Valley The Silicon Valley is notorious for the individual and collective success of its firms. [SEP] So much so that the name ‘Silicon Valley’ has
column3: to be synonymous with the electronics industry. [SEP] The region is regarded as the centre for excellence and innovation and has given rise to some of the world’s most influential firms, including Apple, Hewlett Packard, and Intel. [SEP] Since its inception the Valley has operated with an individualistic open labour market. [SEP] Today, the learning advantages that emanate from associated boundaryless career behaviour are regarded as a key source of competitive advantage for the region (Saxenian, 1996). [SEP] One can argue that the Valley’s ‘boundarylessness’ is a necessary feature of operating in a dynamic industry that demands constant innovation. [SEP] Proponents point out that, in order to learn and solve the problems encountered in rapid technological advancement, knowledge must be sha

column1: 1995). [SEP] Today, Hewlett’s and Terman’s philosophy permeates the region. [SEP] Despite fierce inter-firm competition, open information exchange is common practice among the region’s producers. [SEP] Several features of the Valley contribute to creating a ‘weak’ environment. [SEP] The high pace of technology and product life cycles, fluidity of firm formation and failure, rapid employee turnover resulting in little com-pany-specific socialisation, as well as a lack of meaningful institutionally based hierarchy, all contribute to an environment in which individuals rely on alternative cues to guide their behaviour. [SEP] For example, in the Valley, technology moves quickly and competition is tough. [SEP] New firms form almost overnight -and many disappear just as quickly. [SEP] When firms
column3: and go like ships in the night it is not surprising that employees tend to identify with their profession, not their company. [SEP] Moreover, people’s loyalty is not only to their profession, but to the host industry region. [SEP] ‘As one local semiconductor executive reportedly noted: ‘‘Many of us wake up in the morning thinking that we work for Silicon Valley Inc.’’ ’ (Saxenian, 1996, p. 23). [SEP] They view job-changing as the norm. [SEP] Average job tenure is in the area of two years, and annual turnover is around 35%, and often higher for smaller firms (Saxenian, 1996). [SEP] As one engineer explained: ‘two or three years is about the max [at a job] for the Valley because there’s always something more interesting across the street’ (Saxenian, p. 28).
